problem:
\begin{problem*}{}{}
  Define a sequence of real numbers
  $\left\{ a_m(j) \right\}_{m\ge 1,j\ge 0}$
  with $a_m(0)=\frac{d}{2^m}$ where $d>0$ and,
  \[
    a_m(j+1) = a_m(j)^2 + 2 a_m(j)
  .\]
Find the limit $\lim_{n \to \infty} a_n(n)$.
\end{problem*}
solution:
\begin{soln}
  Define $b_m(j)=a_m(j)+1$.

  Then note that $b_{m}(j+1)=b_m(j)^2$. Hence $b_m(0)=1+
  \frac{d}{2^m}$. It is easy to derive that $b_m(j)=\left(
  1+\frac{d}{2^m}\right)^{2^j}$ for all $j\ge 0$.

  Therefore $b_m(m)=\left(1+\frac{d}{2^m}\right)^{2^m}$. So,
  \[
    \lim_{m \to \infty}a_m(m)=
    \lim_{m \to \infty} b_m(m)-1=\lim_{m \to \infty}
    \left( 1+\frac{d}{2^m} \right)^{\frac{2^m}{d}\cdot d}-1
    =e^{d}-1.
    \qedhere
  \]
\end{soln}
